==== 6 February â Sunday of Martyrs ====
==== 6 February â Sunday of Martyrs ====
â
During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, and Alexandria had peaceful late-night protests. However, [[gunshot|gunfire]] was heard in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive"/> The same organisers of the "Day of Anger", "Friday of Anger", "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest in what was dubbed the "'''Sunday of Martyrs'''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5046/Egypt/Politics-/Protesters-plan-Coptic-mass-on-Martyrs-Sunday.aspx|title=Protesters plan Coptic mass on 'Martyrs' Sunday'|publisher=[[Al-Ahram]]|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡}}).
+
During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, and Alexandria had peaceful late-night protests. However, [[gunshot|gunfire]] was heard in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive"/> The same organisers of the "Day of Anger", "Friday of Anger", "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest in what was dubbed the "'''Sunday of Martyrs'''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5046/Egypt/Politics-/Protesters-plan-Coptic-mass-on-Martyrs-Sunday.aspx|title=Protesters plan Coptic mass on 'Martyrs' Sunday'|publisher=[[Al-Ahram]]|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡}})<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/6/pray_quddas.aspx?ref=extraclip|title=ØµÙØ§Ø© ÙÙØºØ§Ø¦Ø¨ ÙØªØ±Ø§ÙÙÙ ÙØ¨Ø·ÙØ© Ø¨ÙÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø±ÙØ± ÙÙ (Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡)|publisher=Masrawy|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref>.
Egyptian Christians held mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the central train stations.{{Which?|date=February 2011}}<ref name="aljazlive"/>
Egyptian Christians held mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the central train stations.{{Which?|date=February 2011}}<ref name="aljazlive"/>
